comment: /* Military ethics */ Changed a bit of wording here to make it less US-centric in phrasing, and to remove unnecessary reference to administrative matters

diff.*:
Line 130: Line 130:  
{{Unreferenced section|date=March 2009}}
 
{{Unreferenced section|date=March 2009}}
 
{{See also|Nuremberg Principles|Geneva Conventions}}
 
{{See also|Nuremberg Principles|Geneva Conventions}}
−
Military ethics is a set of practices and philosophy to guide members of the armed forces to act in a manner consistent with the values and standards as established by military tradition, and to actively clarify and enforce these conditions rigorously in its administrative structure. The Department of Defense 5500.7-R (DoD 5500.7-R), serves as the primary regulatory source of ethical standards and conduct to members of the Armed Services (DoD, pg 1). Since this is the only order used, all changes must be made by revision.{{POV-statement|date=May 2011}}
+
Military ethics is a set of practices and philosophy to guide members of the armed forces to act in a manner consistent with the values and standards as established by military tradition, and to actively clarify and enforce these conditions rigorously in its administrative structure. For the United States, the Department of Defense 5500.7-R (DoD 5500.7-R), serves as the primary regulatory source of ethical standards and conduct to members of the Armed Services (DoD, pg 1). Since this is the only order used, all changes must be made by revision.{{POV-statement|date=May 2011}}
    −
Military ethics is evolutionary and the administrative structure is modified as new ethical perspectives consistent with national interests evolve.
+
Military ethics is seen as evolutionary and may be modified as new ethical perspectives consistent with national interests evolve.
